notesStmt.p: The “Discourse on Angels and Pagans” is found in the entries for the years 1110 and 1111 in the Hypatian Chronicle, an East Slavonic compilation believed to have been produced in the late thirteenth or early fourteenth century. The first part of the Hypatian is the text conventionally called the Russian Primary Chronicle in English. “Russian” in this case is a misnomer, because it refers to Rus (Rus'), the medieval realm whose heritage is claimed by Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus.

The scholarly consensus is that the Primary Chronicle was compiled in Kiev (Kyev) in the 1110s; its earliest surviving copy is from 1377. There are several redactions of the Primary Chronicle. Differences between them are rather minor, with the exception of the entries for 1110 and 1111.

In all the redactions, these entries report a military expedition into the steppe launched from Kiev, with the intention to retaliate for past, and prevent future, raids by the Cumans (also known as Kipchaks, Qipchaqs, and Polovtsians), a pagan nomadic people living to the south of Rus. According to the chronicler, the chief organizer of this expedition was Prince Vladimir Monomakh (1152-1125). He was inspired to fight the Cumans by an angel who appeared in the Kievan Caves monastery in the form of a fiery pillar; during the battle, angels helped the Rus troops. This narrative is present in all the redactions of the Primary Chronicle. However, only the version found in the Hypatian compilation contains the lengthy discourse on angels and pagans presented here.

Its manner of argumentation is typical of medieval treatises: the author interprets quotations from Christian Scripture, patristic literature, and other authoritative texts; however, it is hard to find parallels to the subject matter and main thesis of this discourse.

The author begins with a quotation from the fourth-century church father Epiphanius of Salamis, stating that the elements and forces of nature each have their own angel; he then extrapolates from this statement to argue that, therefore, angels are also appointed to countries and peoples, including the Cumans. To refute an objection that pagans cannot have angels, the author uses the medieval legend about an angel guiding Alexander the Great in his conquests. Next, to argue that an angel can be appointed to a collectivity and not only to an individual, he refers to the “angel of the church in Smyrna” from the New Testament (Rev 2:8), and then uses Biblical quotations to show that the Archangel Michael was appointed as the angel of the Jewish people as a whole, and that another angel was appointed to the Persians.

Apparently, the argument is as follows. If angels were appointed to the Jewish people and to churches, then it is possible for a collectivity to have an angel. If Alexander the Great was led by an angel, then it is possible for a pagan to have an angel. Therefore, it is possible for a pagan collectivity to have its own angel, which is further confirmed by references to the angel of the Persians. Likewise, the Cumans have their own angel, who leads them when they make war on Rus, which they do on God’s command, as punishment for sins of the Rus people.

The unknown medieval Christian author offers an inclusive, integrative view of the world, where God-appointed angels watch over every force of nature and every ethnic group, regardless of its religion. Pagans, including those fighting against the Christians, are not inherently evil; they play a role in God's plan for humanity. The example of Alexander the Great, whose portrayal in the Primary Chronicle is very laudatory, shows that pagans sometimes represent forces of good. A parallel with Alexander casts a positive light on the Cumans, which, taken together with the fighting against them reported in the same chronicle entries, creates a complex, rich picture of relations between Christian Rus and the pagan steppe.

So far, this text has received very little scholarly attention. Back in 1957, André Vaillant made an important contribution when he identified the sources of some of the erudite quotations in the entries for 1110-1111. However, he viewed the discourse as a whole as an inept string of random passages from unrelated texts. The next work on the subject appeared in 2001, when Alan Timberlake interpreted the entries for 1110-1111 as evidence for a “dialectic” worldview of the chronicler, who believed that angels may sometimes be “malevolent,” although the angel of the Cumans is never described as malevolent in the original text.

Yulia Mikhailova (the present translator) interprets the discourse on angels as a statement on the inter-ethnic and inter-faith relations in southern Rus, which was a borderland between the Christian sedentary agriculturalists and pagan nomadic pastoralists. Their relations included not only military conflicts, but also alliances, intermarriages, and other peaceful interactions. The discourse on angels and pagans explained how such interactions were possible in spite of intermittent hostilities.

The Hypatian Chronicle compilation containing the redaction of the Primary Chronicle with the discourse on angels and pagans survived in the Hypatian Codex (datable to the 1420s), the Khlebnikov Codex (datable to the 1550s-1660s), and in several copies of the Khlebnikov. It is unknown when the discourse on angels and pagans was composed. Numerous errors of inattention suggest that the Hypatian scribe copied an earlier text rather than composing the discourse himself. The discourse is placed at the end of the text of the early twelfth-century Primary Chronicle, which, in the Hypatian, transitions into the Kievan Chronicle, believed to have been compiled in 1198/9. Both of these twelfth-century chronicles, the Primary and Kievan, devote much attention to relations with the pagan neighbors of Rus, making it probable that the “Discourse on Angels and Pagans,” which conceptualizes these relations, was composed in the twelfth century.

sourceDesc.p: Tvorogov, O. V., ed. Povest vremennykh let. Biblioteka literatury drevnei Rusi, vol. 1, edited by D. S. Likhachev et al. St. Petersburg: Nauka, 1997. pp. 62-315. The translated entries are found on pp. 296-304. Available as an electronic text at http://lib.pushkinskijdom.ru/Default.aspx?tabid=4869. Accessed 14 July 2021.

The series Polnoe sobranie russkikh letopisei (The Complete collection of Russian Chronicles) cited below contains the best scholarly editions of East Slavonic chronicles, including A. A. Shakhmatov's edition of the Hypatian. However, the old Cyrillic script and representations of ligatures and other features of medieval manuscripts present in this edition make it very difficult to use it as a basis for a transcription that would be readable with most internet browsers. Therefore, for the transcription, I used the online open-source edition by Tvorogov, which presents the same text as Shakhmatov's edition, but employs modern Cyrillic characters, simplified orthography, sentence breaks, and modern punctuation. Sentence breaks and punctuation in my transcription are slightly different from those in Tvorogov's edition.

projectDesc.p: "Discourse on Angels and Pagans" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS) , a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: The original text presented here is based on the edition by O. V. Tvorogov: Povest vremennykh let. Biblioteka literatury drevnei Rusi, vol. 1, edited by D. S. Likhachev et al. St. Petersburg: Nauka, 1997. pp. 62-315 (available as an electronic text at http://lib.pushkinskijdom.ru/Default.aspx?tabid=4869). The translated entries are found on pp. 296-304. The “Discourse on Angels and Pagans” apparently went through an unknown number of copying stages, accumulating scribal errors. It includes quotations from Greek texts in sometimes awkward Slavonic translations. The original does not have sentence breaks, and the syntax is often ambiguous. Where possible, I checked the quoted passages found in the discourse against the other known Slavonic translations of the same texts and/or the Greek originals. A long quotation from a Slavonic translation of the Byzantine Chronicle by George Hamartolos is represented in italics. Words and phrases supplied by me to clarify the text for the reader are put in square brackets. Emendations are noted and explained. To render Church Slavonic Biblical quotations, I used the corresponding passages from the King James Bible.

Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Якоже пишеть премудрый Епифаний: «Къ коей же твари ангелъ приставленъ:
app.rdg:
As the wise Epiphanius
The fourth-century church father Epiphanius of Salamis (d. 403 CE).
writes, “An angel is appointed to each creation,

app.lem: ангелъ облакомъ и мъгламъ, и снѣгу, и граду, и мразу, ангелъ гласомъ и громомъ,
app.rdg: to clouds, and fogs, and snow, and hail, and frost. There are angels for sounds and for thunders,

app.lem: ангелъ зимы, и зноеви, и осени, и весны, и лѣта, всему духу
app.rdg: angels of winter, of heat, of autumn, spring, and summer. [And angels are appointed] to all the spirits

app.lem: твари его на земли, и тайныя бездны, и суть скровены подъ землею,
app.rdg: of His creation on the earth, and to secret abysses, and to what is hidden under the earth,

app.lem: и преисподьнии тьмы, и сущи връху безны,
app.rdg: and to the darkness beneath the earth, and to the darkness in the abyss

app.lem: бывшия древле верху земля, от неяже тмы, вечеръ, и нощь, и свѣтъ, и день».
app.rdg:
that was once above the earth which gave origin to the evening, and the night, and light, and the day.”
A quotation from On Weights and Measures by Epiphanius. The corresponding Greek passage in an English translation reads: “God did twenty-two works between the beginning and the seventh day, which are these: On the first day, the upper heavens, the earth, the waters - of which consist snow, ice, hail, frost, and dew - and the spirits that minister before him. They are the angels before his face, the angels of glory, the angels of the winds that blow, the angels of the clouds and of the cloud-darknesses, of snow and hail and frost, the angels of sounds, of the thunders and the lightnings, the angels of the cold and of the heat, of winter, fall, spring, and summer, and of all the spirits of his creatures in heaven and on earth. The abysses, both that which is beneath the earth and that of the gulf of darkness that was above the abyss of the waters which were at one time upon the earth, whence the darkness - the evening and the night; the light - of the day and of the morning.” James Elmer Dean, Epiphanius's Treatise On Weights and Measures. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1935, available as an electronic text at http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/epiphanius_weights_02_intro.htm. According to Dean, “Epiphanius would distinguish between the abyss of Sheol and the abysmal waters that in Gen.1:2 are said to have covered the entire earth,” A Slavonic translation of this passage is found in the Greek and Roman Chronicle , a Slavonic compilation that includes a number of translated Greek texts.

app.lem: Ко всимъ тваремъ ангели приставлени. Tако же ангелъ приставленъ къ которой убо земли,
app.rdg: Angels are appointed to all creation. In the same way, an angel is appointed to each land,

app.lem: да соблюдають куюжьто землю, аще суть и погани. Аще Божий гнѣвъ будеть на кую убо землю,
app.rdg: to guard all lands, even if they are pagan. In the case of God's anger at a certain land,

app.lem: повелѣвая ангелу тому на кую убо землю бранью ити,
app.rdg: God commands one of those angels to wage a war against that land,

app.lem: то оной землѣ ангелъ не вопротивится повелѣнью Божью.
app.rdg: and the angel of the land [commanded to wage a war] does not disobey God's command.

app.lem: Яко и се бяше, и на ны навелъ Богъ, грѣхъ ради нашихъ, иноплеменникы поганыя,
app.rdg:
Likewise, God sent pagan aliens
These “pagan aliens” are Cumans (also known as Kipchaks, Qipchaqs, and Polovtsians), a pagan nomadic people living in the steppe to the south of Rus, on the territory of modern-day Ukraine and southern Russia.
against us on account of our sins,

app.lem: и побѣжахуть ны повелѣньемъ Божьимъ, они бо бяху водими аньеломъ по повелѣнью Божью.
app.rdg: and they won by God's command, for they were led by an angel by God's command.

app.lem: Аще ли кто речеть, яко аньела нѣсть у поганыхъ, да слышить, яко Олександру Макидоньскому,
app.rdg:
If someone says that pagans do not have angels, let him hear how Alexander of Macedon,
Alexander the Great.

app.lem: ополчившю на Дарья и пошедшю ему, и побидившю землю всю от въстокъ и до западъ,
app.rdg: while preparing to fight against Darius, after he defeated the whole earth from East to West,

app.lem: 15. и поби землю Егупетьскую, и поби Арама, и приде в островы морьскыя;
app.rdg: 15. crushed Egypt and Aram, arrived to the sea islands

app.lem: и врати лице свое взыти въ Ерусалимъ, побидити жиды, занеже бяху мирни со Дарьемь.
app.rdg: and turned toward Jerusalem, to crush the Jews because they were on friendly terms with Darius.

app.lem: И поиде со вси вои его, и ста на товарищи, и почи.
app.rdg: And when he was on the march with all his soldiers, he pitched a camp and went to sleep.

app.lem: И приспѣ ночь, и лежа на ложи своемь посредѣ шатра, отверзъ очи свои, види мужа,
app.rdg: The night came, and, when he was lying in his bed inside the tent, he opened his eyes and saw a man

app.lem: стояща над нимь и мѣчь нагъ в руцѣ его, и обличие меча его яко молонии.
app.rdg: standing above him, a naked sword in his hand, and the appearance of the sword was like lightning.

app.lem: И запряже мечемь своимъ на главу цареву. И ужасеся цесарь велми и рече:
app.rdg: And this man made to strike the emperor's head, and the emperor was terrified greatly and said,

app.lem: «Не бий мене». И рече ему ангелъ: «Посла мя Богь уимати цесарѣ великии предъ тобою
app.rdg: “Do not strike me!” And the angel said, “God sent me to subdue great emperors

app.lem: и люди многи, азъ же хожю предъ тобою, помагая ти. А нынѣ вѣдай,
app.rdg: and many people before you. Indeed, I walk before you, assisting you. However, now learn that you

app.lem: яко умьреши, понеже помыслилъ еси взити въ Ерусалимъ, зло створити ерѣемъ Божьимъ и к людемъ его».
app.rdg: will die because you want to take Jerusalem and to harm God's priests and His people.”

app.lem: И рече царь: «Молю тя, о Господи, отпусти нынѣ грѣхъ раба твоего, аче не любо ти, а ворочюся дому моему».
app.rdg: And the emperor said, “I pray you, oh Lord, forgive your servant's sin now. If this does not please you, I will return home.”

app.lem: И рече ангелъ: «Не бойся, иди путемъ твоимъ къ Иерусалиму,
app.rdg: And the angel said, “Do not fear, proceed on your way to Jerusalem, and you

app.lem: и узриши ту въ Ерусалими мужа въ обличении моем, и борзо пади на лици своемь,
app.rdg: will see there, in Jerusalem, a man with the same appearance as me. Fall down on your face at once

app.lem: и поклонися мужу тому, и все, еже речеть к тобѣ, створи, не прѣступи рѣчи ему.
app.rdg: and bow down before that man. Do everything that he tells you and do not disobey his words.

app.lem: В онь же день приступиши рѣчь его, и умреши».
app.rdg: On the day you disobey his words, you will die.”

app.lem: И въставъ, цесарь иде въ Ерусалимъ и, пришедъ, въспроси ерѣевъ: «Иду ли на Дарья?»
app.rdg: The emperor got up and went to Jerusalem, and after he came there, he asked the priests, “Should I go against Darius?”

app.lem: И показаша ему книги Данила пророка и рекоша ему: «Ты еси козелъ, а онъ овенъ,
app.rdg: And they showed him the books of the prophet Daniel and told him, “You are the goat, and he is the ram,

app.lem: и потолчеши и возмеши царство его».
app.rdg:
and you will stamp upon him and will take over his empire.”
Dan. 8.

app.lem: Се убо не ангелъ ли вожаше Олексаньдра, не поганъ ли побѣжаше
app.rdg: Therefore, was not this an angel who led Alexander? Did not he win his victories while being a pagan,

app.lem: и вси елини кумирослужебници? Тако и си погании попущени грѣхъ ради нашихъ.
app.rdg:
as all the Greeks were idol-worshipers? In the same way, these pagans
Cumans.
were allowed to win on account of our sins.

app.lem: Се же вѣдомо буди, яко въ хрестьянехъ не единъ ангелъ,
app.rdg: Let it be known that there is not just one angel among the Christians,

app.lem: но елико крестишася, паче же къ благовѣрнымъ княземъ нашимъ.
app.rdg: but there are as many of them as there are baptized persons; in particular, [guardian angels are appointed] to our pious princes.

app.lem: Но противу Божью повеленью не могуть противитися, но молять Бога прилѣжно за хрестьяньскыя люди.
app.rdg: But these angels cannot act contrary to God's command; but they ardently pray to God on behalf of the Christian people.

app.lem: Якоже и бысть: молитвами святыя Богородица и святыхъ ангелъ умилосердися Богъ и посла
app.rdg: This occurred when God showed his mercy because of the prayers of the Holy Mother of God and the holy angels,

app.lem: ангелы в помощь русьскимъ княземъ на поганыя. Якоже рече и
app.rdg:
and He sent angels to help the Rus princes against the pagans,
Cumans.
in the same way as when He said to

app.lem: Моисѣеви: «Се ангелъ мой прѣдыпоидеть предъ лицемъ твоимъ».
app.rdg:
Moses, “Behold, my angel shall go before you.”
Ex. 23:20.
.

app.lem: Якоже рекохомъ прѣже, зьнаменье се бысть мѣсяца февраля въ 11 день, исходяще сему лѣту 18.
app.rdg:
As we said above, this portent occurred on the eleventh day of February at the end of this [66]18th year
The fiery pillar that appeared in the Kievan Caves monastery, which the Primary Chronicle interprets as an appearance of an angel. Year 6618 “from the creation of the world” corresponds to 1110 CE.
.

desc.hi: An account of the expedition to the steppe and a victory over the Cumans follows, which is omitted here.

app.lem: И въпросиша колодникъ, глаголюще:
app.rdg: [After the battle with the Cumans, the Rus princes] asked the prisoners and said,

app.lem: «Како васъ толка сила и многое множество не могосте ся противити, но воскорѣ побѣгостѣ?»
app.rdg: “How come there were such a great force and such a great multitude of you, and you could not resist us and fled so soon?”

app.lem: Си же отвѣщеваху, глаголюще: «Како можемъ битися с вами, а друзии ѣздяху верху васъ въ оружьи свѣтлѣ и страшни, иже помагаху вамъ?»
app.rdg: And they answered, “How could we fight against you when some others rode above you, terrifying, with shining weapons, and helped you?”

app.lem: Токмо се суть ангели, от Бога послани помогатъ хрестьяномъ.
app.rdg: These could only be angels sent by God to help the Christians.

app.lem: Се бо ангелъ вложи въ сердце Володимеру Манамаху поустити братью свою на иноплеменникы, русьскии князи.
app.rdg:
For it was an angel who inspired Vladimir Monomakh to call on his brethren, the Rus princes, to go against the aliens.
Cumans.

app.lem: Се бо, якоже рекохомъ, видинье видиша в Печерьскомъ манастыри, еже стояше столпъ огненъ на тряпезници,
app.rdg: As we mentioned above, we had a vision in the Caves monastery, when a fiery pillar stood on the refectory

app.lem: таже преступѣ на церковь и оттуда к Городцю; ту бо бяше Володимеръ в Радосыни.
app.rdg:
and from there it moved towards Gorodets, for Vladimir was there in Radosyn.
Radosyn was a settlement near the fortress Gorodets on the Dnieper River.

app.lem: И тогда се ангелъ вложи Володимеру въ сердце, нача понужати, якоже рекохомъ.
app.rdg:
Behold, it was then that the angel inspired Vladimir, and he started to urge [other princes to make an anti-Cuman campaign], as we mentioned above.
The following text in italics is based on the Slavonic translation of the ninth-century Byzantine Chronicle by George Hamartolos.

lem.hi: Тѣмже достойно похволяти ангелы, якоже Иоанъ Златоустець рече:

rdg.hi:
This is why we ought to praise angels, as John Chrysostom
The work quoted by Hamartolos is Oratio in Synaxin Archangelorum by the early Christian author known as pseudo-Chrysostom. André Vaillant, “Les citations des années 1110-1111 dans la chronique de Kiev,” Byzantinoslavica , vol. 18, 1957, pp. 18-38, at 24.
said,

lem.hi: ибо ти Творцю безначално поють, милостиву ему быти и тиху человѣкомъ.

rdg.hi: for they forever sing praise to God so that he might show mercy and peace to humans.

lem.hi: Ангелы бо, глаголю, наша поборникы, на противныя силы воюющимъ, имьже есть архангелъ

rdg.hi: For angels, I say, are our defenders when we fight against our enemy's forces,

lem.hi: Михаилъ, ибо со дьяволомъ тѣла ради Моисиева противяся,

rdg.hi:
and their commander
The word in the original is “archangel,” apparently used in its literal Greek meaning, “chief angel,” thus “their archangel” is “their leader” or “commander.” is Michael because he fought with the Devil over Moses's body,
Jude 9.

lem.hi: на князь же перьский свободы ради людьския противяся.

rdg.hi: and he took arms against the Persian prince [that is, the angel of the Persians] for the sake of the [Jewish] people's freedom.

lem.hi: Повеленьемь Божьимъ всю тварь раздѣлити.

rdg.hi:
Angels divided
In the original, the word is razdeliti, “to divide.” The corresponding passage in the Slavonic translation of Hamartolos has razdelivshe, “having divided”; razdeliti apparently is a scribal error. Furthermore, in the Slavonic translation, the syntax of this sentence is very awkward, and “having divided” appears to lack the grammatical referent. In the Greek text by Hamartolos, angels, according to God's command, divided all of creation, including the most important peoples/ethnicities, each of which received their own angel. all of creation according to God's command.

lem.hi: И языкомъ старишины наставляюще, cимъ же нѣкоего перьсямъ презрѣти оправда,

rdg.hi:
While appointing governors to peoples, God judged that one of the angels should watch over
In the original, the word is prozreti, “to foresee, to prophesize”; the corresponding passage in the Slavonic translation of Hamartolos has prezreti, “to watch over”; prozreti apparently is a scribal error. the Persians,

lem.hi: Михаила же сущимъ обрѣзаномъ людемъ схранити повелѣ.

rdg.hi:
and he commanded Michael to guard the circumcised people,
The Jews.

lem.hi: Съставити же предѣлы ихъ прогнѣваньемь, не по грѣховьныя ярости, но от божествьнаго нѣкоего неизреченьнаго слова;

rdg.hi:
He established boundaries for them
The Slavonic translator misinterpret the Greek text here and translated the Greek eforois (guardians) as “limits.” In the Greek text, God established one angel as the guardian of the Persians and Michael as the guardian of the Jews. See Vera Matveenko, Liudmila Shchegoleva, eds., Vremennik Georgia Monakha (Khronika Georgia Amartola) (Moscow: Bogorodskii pechatnik, 2000), p. 398. in anger, but not in sinful furious anger, but according to a certain secret divine
In the original, the word is blazhenago, “blessed”; the corresponding passage in the Slavonic translation of Hamartolos has bozhestv'nago, “divine.” Both words were often written in an abbreviated form, making it easy to confuse them. In the Greek original of Hamartolos, the word translated into Slavonic as “divine word” is logos, which in Greek also meant “reason.” word.
In the original Greek text by Hamartolos, God commanded the angel of the Jews Michael to contest with the angel of the Persians over the freedom of the Jewish people. This contest was ordained for a mysterious reason (aporreton logon); apparently, the author sought to express the idea of God's inscrutable ways. One redaction of Hamartolos adds that God commanded this contest in anger (kata pathos orges). This remark may have been based on Zech. 1:12, where the prayer of the angel, whom Hamartolos identifies as Michael, mentions that God has been angry with the Jews for seventy years. The Slavonic translator elaborated on the short phrase kata pathos orges, explaining that God's righteous anger was different from sinful anger (fury) of humans. This explanation is not present in Hamartolos.

app.lem: И се пакы, якоже Иполитъ глаголеть, толкуеть Данила:
app.rdg:
Also, as Hippolytus
Hippolytus of Rome (c. 170 – c. 235 CE), a theologian, whose works include the Commentary on the Prophet Daniel. says, interpreting the Book of Daniel,

app.lem: «В лѣто третьее Кура цесаря, азъ Данилъ плакахъся три недѣли.
app.rdg: “'In the third year of the reign of Emperor Cyrus, I, Daniel, was mourning for three weeks.

app.lem: Перваго же мѣсяца смирихся, моля Бога дьний 20 и 1, прося от него откровенья тайны.
app.rdg: And in the first month I humbled myself, praying to God for twenty-one days, asking him to reveal the secret.

app.lem: И, услышавъ, Отець пусти слово свое, кажа хотящее быти имъ.
app.rdg:
And the Father heard me and sent his
In the original, the word is tvoe, “your,” apparently written accidentally instead of svoe, “his.” word to me, showing by it what shall happen.

app.lem: И бысть на велицѣ рѣцѣ, лѣпо бяшеть ту ся явити, идѣже хотяше и грѣхи отпущати.
app.rdg:
This occurred by the side of the great river.
Dan. 10: 1-4. The word “river” is omitted in the original. It was fitting for God to reveal himself there, where he would in the future forgive sins.
According to Hippolytus, the Tigris, the “great river,” on the bank of which Daniel had his vision, prefigures the River Jordan. Philip Schaff, Fathers of the Third Century: Hippolytus, Cyprian, Caius, Novatian (New York: Christian Literature Company, 1885), p. 182.

app.lem: И возведъ очи свои, видѣхъ: и се мужь одѣнъ в багоръ. Первый рече видѣньемь,
app.rdg:
'And I raised my eyes and saw a man clad in purple.' At first sight,
The Khlebnikov manuscript has “at first sight”; the Hypatian has “the first one,” probably referring to Daniel's previous vision of the Archangel Gabriel (Dan. 8: 16). Both versions convey the idea that this vision looked similar to the appearance of Gabriel, but was, in fact, a vision of God. he said, he had the appearance

app.lem: аки Гаврилъ ангелъ летя, сдѣ же не тако, но видъ самого Господа,
app.rdg: of the flying Angel Gabriel, but this was not so in this case, [as] it was the appearance of the Lord himself,

app.lem: видъ же не свершена человѣка, но образомъ человѣкомъ являющася, якоже глаголеть:
app.rdg: not the appearance of the perfect Man, but appearing in the image of a man, as he [Daniel] says,

app.rdg: and his face as the appearance of lightning, and his eyes as lamps of fire, and his arms and his feet

are similar to polished brass, and the voice of his words like the voice of a multitude.

Dan. 10:10. And he said unto me, 'Fear not, Daniel. Knowest thou wherefore I come unto thee?
